0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-arizona-idUSKBN12X2KZ	Appeals court revives challenge to Arizona voting law	"

A U.S. appeals court on Wednesday agreed to revisit a challenge to an Arizona voting law which restricted the ability of advocates to collect absentee ballots by hand. A three judge 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals had earlier upheld the Arizona law
column2: but the full court on Wednesday voted to rehear the case before an 11-judge panel. Five conservative 9th Circuit judges dissented from the decision to rehear the case
column3: saying it was made too close to Election Day.

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-lawsuit-idUSKBN12X1Y0	Trump's campaign should be fair game in Trump University trial: lawyers	"
By David Ingram
Statements Donald Trump has made during his presidential run should generally be admissible in an upcoming civil trial over alleged fraud at his Trump University venture
column2: lawyers for the plaintiffs said in a court filing late on Tuesday.Some of the statements by the Republican nominee may be helpful to jurors as they try to determine Trump's credibility
column3: the lawyers wrote
column4: calling his credibility a central issue.Students at Trump University have sued in a federal court in San Diego
column5: claiming they were defrauded by its real estate seminars. A trial is set to begin on Nov. 28.

column1: Last month
column2: Trump's attorneys said evidence and statements from the election campaign should be barred from the trial because they could unfairly prejudice the jury. Their request would include allegations of sexual misconduct
column3: which Trump has denied during the campaign.Lawyers for the plaintiffs said Trump's request was far too broad
column4: threatening to exclude a ""melange of misrepresentations
column5: falsehoods and flip-flops"" that would impeach Trump's credibility as a witness.

column1: In the course of the campaign
column2: news organizations have collected and publicized practically every known Trump falsehood over the years
column3: bringing all such statements within the gambit of Trump's motion

column1: A lawyer for Trump could not immediately be reached for comment on Wednesday.  (Reporting by David Ingram in New York; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Cochran'

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-guns-idUSKBN12X11X	Gun control groups spend millions on state ballot initiatives	"
By Joseph Ax
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Gun safety advocates are pouring tens of millions of dollars into Maine and Nevada to support ballot initiatives that would mandate background checks for gun sales in an effort to clinch state-level victories after years of failed drives in Congress.The avalanche of money spent on supporting such initiatives ahead of the Nov. 8 vote could hand gun control organizations their biggest win since they failed to secure the passage of federal legislation after the massacre of 26 children and educators at a Newtown
column2: Connecticut
column3: elementary school in December 2012.Voters in California and Washington state will also cast ballots on gun control initiatives
column4: and opinion polls show the measures are likely to pass in all four states.     Everytown for Gun Safety
column5: the gun control group founded by billionaire former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg
column7: throwing its financial weight behind three of the four measures. The organization plans to spend $25 million nationwide on the issue
column8: almost as much as the powerful National Rifle Association has spent on television advertising for Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump.The right to own firearms is protected by the Second Amendment of the U.S. Constitution
column9: and any efforts to restrict that guarantee are fought vehemently by gun rights advocates
column10: who are highly influential within the Republican Party.Victories by gun control groups in Maine and Nevada would mean that half of the U.S. population would live in states with expanded background checks
column11: including private sales not involving a licensed dealer.Gun control supporters say that would be a symbolic and strategically important threshold.Opponents of the measures say the laws are poorly written
column12: would do little to combat crime and would punish law-abiding gun owners.

column1: A University of New Hampshire poll in late October found 52 percent of Maine residents support the measure and 43 percent oppose it. In Nevada
column2: two polls in late October found a 16-percentage-point margin and a 25-point margin in favor of the initiative
column3: respectively.The measures come in a year that voters around the United States will weigh in on 71 citizen-submitted ballot initiatives on topics ranging from marijuana legalization to raising the minimum wage
column4: the largest number in a decade
column6: a website that tracks voting data.EXPENSIVE BATTLEGROUND

column1: Everytown described its strategy as part of an effort to copy the state-by-state tactic that helped legalize gay marriage across the United States
column2: with Congress unwilling to pass universal background check legislation.""One of the great advantages of going directly to the electorate is that you can go around the legislative bodies and make law
column3: said Zach Silk
column4: a consultant who has worked with Everytown in Nevada and previously helped oversee Washington state's 2014 successful background-check ballot initiative.Nevada in particular has become an expensive battleground. Bloomberg has personally donated nearly $10 million to the effort there
column5: and Nevadans for Background Checks had collected $14.3 million as of Oct. 18. That is nearly triple the $4.8 million that the leading opposition group
column9: supporters of background checks have outspent opponents by more than 5-to-1
column10: with the Everytown-backed Mainers for Responsible Gun Ownership Fund reporting $5.3 million in contributions as of last week.

column1: The NRA did not respond to a request for comment on its campaign spending decisions.Critics have accused Bloomberg of trying to buy victory. ""This law is convoluted and way overregulatory
column2: said David Trahan
column3: the executive director of the Sportsman's Alliance of Maine and a former state legislator. ""It reflects the person funding this initiative
column4: Michael Bloomberg. His solutions are overkill
column5: and they border on social engineering.""But Everytown's executive director
column7: said it was the gun lobby that has tried to take power away from the citizenry.""While the NRA can control legislators and the government
column9: he said. (Reporting by Joseph Ax; Editing by Scott Malone and Jonathan Oatis)"	['Trump']	['gay']

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKBN12W47H	Clinton camp says FBI should say what it knows about Trump's Russia ties	"
By Mark Hosenball and Roberta Rampton
| WASHINGTON/FT. LAUDERDALE
column2: Fla.

column1: WASHINGTON/FT. LAUDERDALE
column2: Fla. A top aide to Hillary Clinton urged the FBI on Tuesday to disclose what it knows about any ties between Donald Trump and Russia
column3: accusing the agency of unfairly publicizing its inquiry into Clinton's email practices while staying quiet about the Republican presidential candidate.The Federal Bureau of Investigation opened a preliminary inquiry in recent months into allegations that Trump or his associates might have had questionable dealings with Russian people or businesses
column4: but found no evidence to warrant opening a full investigation
column5: according to sources familiar with the matter. The agency has not publicly discussed the probe.A week before Election Day
column6: the Clinton campaign was trying to contain damage from the announcement by FBI Director James Comey on Friday that his agency was looking into newly discovered emails that might relate to Clinton's use of a private server while she was secretary of state.Clinton has voiced confidence the FBI will not find anything problematic.She campaigned on Tuesday in the battleground state of Florida
column7: where she was joined in Dade City by former Miss Universe Alicia Machado
column8: whom Trump had mocked for gaining weight. Chants of ""Lock her up!"" from dozens of Trump supporters gathered nearby could be faintly heard while Clinton spoke.In Ft. Lauderdale
column10: ""She's a liar"" was escorted out of the rally. Several other protesters removed during the course of her speech.""I am sick and tired of the negative
column13: dangerous vision and behavior from people who support Donald Trump
column14: Clinton said as another protester was removed from the rally.Trump and other Republicans have seized on Comey's announcement
column15: which did not indicate any wrongdoing by Clinton
column16: to ratchet up criticism of the Democratic candidate. She leads in most opinion polls ahead of the Nov. 8 election.Trump urged people on Tuesday who voted early for his Democratic rival to cancel their ballots and switch to him.""This is a message for any Democratic voters who have already cast their ballots for Hillary Clinton and who are having a bad case of buyer's remorse
column17: in other words you want to change your vote
column18: Trump told a Wisconsin rally.""So if you live here or in Michigan or Pennsylvania or Minnesota
column19: you can change your vote to Donald Trump.""

column1: Several states
column2: including those cited by Trump
column3: have a process to allow voters who cast early ballots to change their votes
column4: either by submitting new ballots or showing up at their polling place on Election Day. 'CONNECTIONS TO THE RUSSIANS'

column1: Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook questioned why the FBI director had not released any information about the agency's Russia inquiries.""If you're in the business of releasing information about investigations on presidential candidates
column2: release everything you have on Donald Trump. Release the information on his connections to the Russians
column3: Mook said on CNN.The FBI inquiry reviewed allegations that Trump or his associates might have violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act or engaged in contacts or commerce with people in Russia who are subject to U.S. or international financial sanctions.

column1: The U.S. government has blamed Russia for cyber attacks on Democratic Party organizations. Democrats criticize Trump for taking what they say is a pro-Russia foreign policy stance.Russia's possible role in the campaign again came into focus when online magazine Slate said a group of computer scientists had been alarmed by records showing thousands of apparent connection attempts between an email server operated on behalf of the Trump Organization and computers inside a Russian company
column2: Alfa Bank in Moscow.Trump campaign spokeswoman Hope Hicks said the server
column3: which had been used to send out hotel marketing material
column4: had been dormant for years.               Prominent U.S. cyber security company FireEye said it had been hired by Alfa Bank to investigate the records and had been granted access to the bank's systems in Moscow to look for evidence of any relationship with Trump's company or any signs of hacking or infection. FireEye said so far it had found no emails being sent back and forth or any other link.

column1: CLINTON POLL LEAD

Opinion polls showed Clinton's lead has narrowed slightly since early last week but it was too early to say whether the email controversy was hurting her.Clinton led businessman Trump in the latest Reuters/Ipsos poll of likely voters released on Monday
column2: by 44 percent to 39 percent. Clinton
column3: hoping to be the first woman elected president
column4: strengthened her lead over Trump in polls after the release last month of a 2005 video in which the Republican bragged in vulgar terms about groping women.        But in a dramatic twist
column5: Comey told Congress in a letter on Friday that the FBI was reviewing the newly discovered emails.Comey had announced in July that the FBI had completed a probe into the email practices
column6: concluding there were no grounds to bring any charges.Clinton's team has been pressing the FBI to provide details on the new trove of emails
column7: which Comey said may or may not be significant in the case. Little is publicly known yet about the emails
column8: other than that they were found during an unrelated probe into former U.S. Representative Anthony Weiner
column9: the estranged husband of top Clinton aide Huma Abedin.Comey's letter has provided Republicans with fresh fodder for attack in the waning days of the campaign. U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan said on Tuesday that a Clinton presidency would bog down in ""scandal baggage.""Congressional Republicans
column10: who had been concerned Trump risked damaging their majorities in the House and Senate
column11: were also encouraged by his recent statements on efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act
column12: popularly known as Obamacare. A campaign aide said if Trump wins
column13: he would ask Congress to begin working on legislation to repeal the law before the Jan. 20 inauguration.  (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson
column16: John Walcott  and Joseph Menn; Writing by Alistair Bell and Ginger Gibson; Editing by Jonathan Oatis

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-banks-analysis-idUSKBN12X0DC	Hillary Clinton: Wall Street's favorite enemy	"
By Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton began her presidential campaign by promising to do what it takes to rein in Wall Street.Boosted by Wall Street's toughest critics
column2: U.S. senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren
column3: the Democratic candidate has declared ""the deck is still stacked in favor of those at the top"" and said she would raise bank fees and tighten banking regulations. She has encouraged regulators to break up too-risky banks.And yet
column4: Wall Street appears unperturbed by the prospect of a Clinton presidency. In fact
column5: the banking industry has supported Clinton with buckets of cash and stocks have sold off on days when the Clinton campaign stumbles. Privately
column6: bankers say that they trust her to remain a pragmatist who will keep the current regulatory regime laid down by the Dodd-Frank Wall Street reform legislation passed in 2010.""I don't think Clinton wakes up thinking about Wall Street
column7: one senior banking industry lobbyist said.There are hints in apparently leaked email discussions among Clinton's campaign staff that bankers are not far off the mark when they count on her to tread lightly. Pressed during the campaign by progressive Democrats to call for a revival of the Glass-Steagall Act that would require separation of commercial and investment banking
column8: Clinton ultimately refused. She also weighed another progressive favorite - a tax on financial transactions- but instead recommended a far narrower plan to tax only canceled orders by high speed traders.Ultimately
column9: what bankers most like about Clinton is that she is not Donald Trump. Many financiers fear her unorthodox Republican rival could disrupt global trade
column10: damage geopolitical relationships and rattle markets
column11: industry analysts and participants say.""Those are the kind of things that corner offices think about
column12: said Karen Shaw Petrou of Federal Financial Analytics Inc
column13: whose firm advises financial firms about U.S. regulatory policy. ""The overriding concern about Trump has dominated people's thinking.""

column1: Trump's candidacy has upended traditional political alliances and bankers that usually contribute more to the Republicans have been flinging money at Clinton.Employees of the 17 largest bank holding companies and their subsidiaries have been sending her $10 for every $1 they contributed to Trump
column2: according to a Reuters analysis. In 2012
column3: the same group contributed twice as much to Republican candidate Mitt Romney as it did to President Barack Obama's re-election campaign.  DEVIL YOU KNOW

column1: People who work for hedge funds and private equity firms have contributed more than $56 million to Clinton's presidential campaign and the supporting groups that face no legal cap on donations. Trump's campaign and related groups received just $243
column2: 000 from donors in the same sector
column3: according to data from the Center for Responsive Politics.""It's basically going with the devil you know over the devil you don't
column4: said Brian Gardner
column5: a managing director of New York investment firm Keefe Bruyette & Woods. What also helped
column7: was the familiarity with Hillary and Bill Clinton dating back to the 1990s when her husband was president and ushered in a period of financial deregulation.""There is a closeness and a comfort level between the titans on Wall Street and the Clintons
column9: the biggest worry is a scenario where Clinton wins and the Democrats take control of the House and the Senate
column10: with progressives such as Warren and Sanders holding sway over everything from new tax laws to appointments of regulators.Already
column11: Warren has called for immediate dismissal of the Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Mary Jo White. Last year
column12: Warren successfully led a movement to derail Obama's plan to appoint banker Antonio Weiss to the top job at Treasury.

column1: Warren and other progressives will press Clinton to be tough on Wall Street in return for their campaign support. Clinton ""leaned heavily on Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders
column2: and progressive ideas
column3: when she needed to excite voters
column4: Adam Green with the Progressive Change Campaign Committee said. ""Elizabeth Warren has proven she's a very powerful ally to have on your side. And it's well known she's also a formidable opponent to have against you
column6: recent polls suggest it is unlikely that Democrats will take the House and the future of the Senate is far from certain. Even if the Senate goes Democratic
column7: it is likely to be led by New York Senator Chuck Schumer
column8: a moderate who has represented Wall Street with the industry's backing.Clinton has said she will propose a ""risk fee"" on the largest financial firms and tighten up rules which allow banks to circumvent bans on proprietary trading by investing in hedge funds. Like Trump
column9: she has proposed to end the tax break that private equity investors enjoy
column10: termed ""carried interest.""Yet such provisions will be probably tied up in a much larger tax initiative that will involve months
column11: if not a year or more
column12: of horse trading in Washington. Ultimately
column13: it could end up overshadowed by other progressive goals
column16: or raising the minimum wage.Those are the causes that Clinton has prioritized and they are likely to supersede her anti-bank rhetoric
column17: say bankers. One industry trade group representative said: ""We're not in her top 10 to take care of."" (Reporting by Amanda Becker; Additional reporting by Patrick Rucker in Washington and Olivia Oran and Grant Smith in New York; Editing by Linda Stern and Tomasz Janowski)"	['Sanders'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-mylan-nl-epipen-price-idUSKBN12X003	Senator Grassley asks Defense Department to explain EpiPen spending	"

U.S. Senator Chuck Grassley asked the Department of Defense and the Department of Veterans Affairs on Tuesday to explain spending trends for the EpiPen emergency allergy treatment.The request followed a recent report by Reuters detailing how EpiPen price hikes by manufacturer Mylan NV had added millions to U.S. Department of Defense spending since 2008 as the agency covered more prescriptions for the lifesaving allergy shot at near retail prices.""We know the price increase for EpiPens is hitting individual consumers and Medicare and Medicaid
column2: Grassley
column3: a Republican
column4: said in a statement.  ""We need to determine whether taxpayers overpaid for the EpiPen through the Department of Defense and the VA and whether they deserve a rebate
column5: as they do with Medicaid.  Spending that isn't warranted squeezes the health care budget.""

column1: Mylan agreed last month to pay $465 million to settle questions of whether it underpaid U.S. government healthcare programs by misclassifying EpiPen.
The company raised the price for a package of two EpiPens by sixfold to more than $600 over the last decade.
(Reporting By Deena Beasley; Editing by Andrew Hay)"	['Grassley']	['healthcare']
9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-research-moody-s-idUSKBN12W56J	Moody's Analytics election model predicts Clinton win	"
Low gas prices and President Barack Obama's high approval ratings are key factors that favor Democrat Hillary Clinton winning the White House in next week's election
column2: according to a model from Moody's Analytics that has accurately predicted the last nine U.S. presidential contests.Clinton is forecast to pick up 332 Electoral College votes against 206 for Republican Donald Trump
column3: Moody's Analytics predicted on Tuesday in the final update of its model before Election Day on Nov. 8. That would match Obama's margin of victory over Republican challenger Mitt Romney in 2012.The Reuters-Ipsos States of the Nation project also predicts a Clinton win
column4: with a 95 percent probability of her winning at least 278 electoral votes. A candidate needs to win at least 270 electoral votes to be elected president.The Moody's Analytics model is based on a combination of state-level economic conditions and political history
column5: and has correctly called the outcome of each presidential election since Republican Ronald Reagan unseated Democrat Jimmy Carter in 1980.Rather than focus on the individual candidates in a race
column6: the model instead centers on whether current economic and political conditions favor the incumbent party in the White House. This year those factors point to Clinton becoming the 45th U.S. president.

column1: The economic factors Moody's measures include the two-year percentage changes in real personal income per household
column2: as well as house and gasoline prices. Among the political factors weighed
column3: Moody's said the most important is the share of the vote in any one state that went to the incumbent party in the previous election. It also takes into account voter fatigue and the incumbent president's approval ratings.

column1: This year
column2: with Obama enjoying some of his highest job approval ratings since his first year in office in 2009 and gasoline prices holding steady at well-below-average levels
column3: the model suggests the Democrats will win their third straight presidential election
column4: Moody's said. That would mark the first time since the 1988 election of Republican George H.W. Bush that one party has won three consecutive presidential contests.Moody's warns
column6: that its model does not take into account any individual characteristics of specific candidates.

column1: Given the unusual nature of the 2016 election cycle to date
column2: it is very possible that voters will react to changing economic and political conditions differently than they have in past election cycles
column3: placing some risk in the model outcome
column4: particularly state-by-state projections
column5: Moody's analytics economist Dan White wrote in the report. (Reporting By Dan Burns; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Romney'
